text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from
English with Jennifer. If you've watched

a lot of my lessons, you probably know
some of my interests. Playing the piano

is something I've tried to keep
up with over the years. But I've explored

and experimented.
At different points in my life, I learned

a bit of taekwondo,
origami, and I even signed up for
Hawaiian dance classes.
Take a look at my last sentence. Perhaps it

sounded okay in the flow of speech, but
now that you see it in writing,

you may find a weakness in the structure.
Focus on the three interests I named.
Do you see them?

Taekwondo. Origami.
Hawaiian dance.

The clearest way to list items is to use
parallel structure. That means that all
the items in the list should be grammatically
equal. If I'm going to list three things I
learned, I can list three nouns or noun phrases.
Those are all objects of the verb "learn."

Watch how I rewrite the statement. At
different points in my life,

I learned a bit of taekwondo, origami,
and Hawaiian dance.

In this lesson, we're going to make sure
you can recognize and use

parallel structure. This will make your
statements

clear and easy to understand.
Parallel structure is especially valued

in writing,
whether it's for academic or

professional purposes.
We already looked at a series of nouns.

What if I start my list with a couple of
gerunds?
How do I create parallel structure?

Focus on the verb "perform" and change it
to a gerund.

I enjoyed learning forms in taekwondo,
folding paper flowers, and performing
hula dances.

Can you create parallel structure in
this statement?

Well, the first item is an infinitive. It
was difficult to do what?

To spar, which means to fight with a
partner.

Let's focus on the other actions and
change
those to infinitives.

To deliver high kicks.
To break boards.

IF we create a series a list of
infinitives,

we often use "to" only with the first
infinitive,
so watch how we can rewrite this.

In my taekwondo classes, I found it
difficult to spar with a partner,

deliver high kicks to my opponent's head,
and break boards.

Parallel structure is needed when we use
coordinating conjunctions,
like AND, OR...and when we use correlative conjunctions,
like "either...or."

Can you identify the parallel structure
in each of these statements?

Dancing to beautiful music and
performing for an audience is very exciting.

Did you prefer ancient or modern
Hawaiian dance?

Origami requires patience, accuracy,
and a good memory.

You can either memorize a set of steps
or look at a set of instructions.

Both taekwondo and Hawaiian dance
require coordination.

Keep in mind that I'm showing you
sentences, but we also use

parallel structure in bulleted or
numbered lists.
Take a look.

My favorite activities: playing the piano,
reading, taking walks with my dog.

Do you know how I'm going to change that
last one? I need another

gerund. What do we do with board games?
Play. The gerund? Playing.
Playing board games with my children.

My top excuses for not exercising more:
I'm busy during the day.

I'd rather do something else with my
free time.

I need to change that middle one. Right?
The other items are full statements,

sentences with a subject and a verb.
So, how about, "I'm too tired at night"?

Maybe you'd like to create your own list
in the comments. Before you do, let's
practice some more. I'm going to give you
15-question quiz. Are you ready?
Rewrite each statement using parallel structure.

As a child, I spent a lot of time reading
and playing the piano.

My piano teacher spoke kindly and
patiently.
OR: with kindness and patience.

For a while, I took both piano lessons
and accordion lessons.
OR: took both piano and accordion lessons.

Joining a Filipino association turned
out to be a cultural

and social experience.
OR: It turned out to be a cultural as
well as social experience.

When I first joined, I knew neither the
names of the dances nor the steps.

I not only learned a few different
dances, but I also had the opportunity to
perform them.

I took roller skating lessons, but didn't
reach a really high level.

I have neither tried nor even considered
surfing.

As a girl, I collected stickers, glass
bottles, and yo-yos.

As far as drawing went, I was pretty good
at looking at a model
and copying it.

I was a cheerleader for eight years, and
it helped me: build confidence,

develop a public speaking voice, stay in
shape,
and create some great memories.

If I had had the time, I would have
continued taekwondo and earned a black belt.

Note here how we can omit the auxiliary
verbs and make use of
only the main verb.

For a short time, I learned how to do
tarot card readings,

although I doubted that I could predict
the future

or that someone would want me to do a
reading for them.

It's important to explore new interests
because we can get set in our ways
and then become fearful of new things.

By the time I reach old age, I hope I
will have danced enough dances,

played enough songs, visited enough
places,

seen enough faces, and laughed enough
laughs.

How did you do? Do you feel more
comfortable and confident with parallel
structure? I hope so. Please like and share this
video if you found it useful. As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Thank you to all the members of my
channel and, you Super and Truly

Marvelous Members,
look out for the next bonus video.

Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and
Instagram. And try something new!

Download the app Hallo and join me for
a live stream.

Students can hop on camera and get
speaking practice in real time.
